review.title: On non-iterative training of a neural classifier
review.abstract: Recently an algorithm, was discovered, which separates points in n-dimension by planes in such a manner that no two points are left unseparated by at least one plane{[}1-3{]}. By using this new algorithm we show that there are two ways of classification by a neural network, for a large dimension feature space, both of which are non-iterative and deterministic and we apply both these methods to a classical pattern recognition problem and present the results. It is expected these methods will now be widely used for the training of neural networks for Deep Learning not only because of their non-iterative and deterministic nature but also because of their efficiency and speed and will supercede other classification methods which are iterative in nature and rely on error minimization.

metadata.title: On non-iterative training of a neural classifier

sections.heading: On non-iterative training of a neural classifier
sections.text: K. ESWARAN, Sreenidhi Institute of Science and Technology K. DAMODHAR RAO, Sreenidhi Institute of Science and TechnologyRecently, an algorithm was discovered that separates points in the n-dimension by planes so that no two points remain separated by at least one plane [1-3]. By using this new algorithm, we show that there are two types of classification by a neural network, for a large dimensional space, both of which are non-iterative and deterministic. To demonstrate the power of these two methods, we apply them exhaustively to the classic pattern recognition problem: The Fisher-Andersons, IRIS flower data set and present the results. These methods are now widely expected to be used for forming neural networks for deep learning, not only because of their non-iterative and deterministic nature, but also because of their efficiency and speed.

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: In fact, most of them are able to trump themselves, and they are able to trump themselves, "he said in an interview with the New York Times.

sections.heading: 2.1. An application to Data Classification and Retrieval
sections.text: Suppose you have N points in an n dimension X-space and the algorithm was used to separate all N points, and it was determined after running the algorithm that q levels were finally necessary. We will now show that this information can be used as a data retrieval device. That is, all data can now be stored in such a way that the retrieval can be performed on the other side with great efficiency. 2It is assumed that each level will have a specific (defined) normal direction, a point that lies on the positive side of normality is said to be on the positive side of the plane when the point on the other side is said to be on the negative side. This direction is easy to find if the equation of the plane is known, for example, if 1 + α1x1 + αx2 +..., + αxn = 0 is the equation to a certain dimensional plane.

sections.heading: 2.2. Results on the IRIS FLOWER Classification Problem using Method 1.
sections.text: This year, the number of unemployed residing in Germany has multiplied in recent years. (...) The number of unemployed residing in Germany has doubled in the last ten years. (...) The number of unemployed has doubled in the last ten years. (...) The number of unemployed has doubled in the last ten years. (...) The number of unemployed has doubled. (...) The number of unemployed has tripled in the last ten years. (...) The number of unemployed has tripled. (...) The number of unemployed has tripled. (...) The number of unemployed has tripled. (...) The number of unemployed has tripled. (...) The number of unemployed has tripled. (... The number of unemployed has tripled. (...) The number of unemployed has tripled. (...) The number of unemployed has tripled.

sections.heading: 4. CONCLUSION
sections.text: In this paper, we used a new algorithm that separates points in ndimensional space by planes to develop non-titerative classification techniques to solve pattern recognition problems using neural networks. Methods developed in this paper are very new and will be applied in neural research and deep learning, not only because of their non-titerative and deterministic nature, but also because of their efficiency and speed. It is strongly believed that they have the potential to replace other classification methods that are iterative in nature and rely on error minimization.

sections.heading: 5. ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS
sections.text: The authors thank the management of Sreenidhi: Dr. P. Narsimaha Reddy and Dr. K.T Mahi for their sustained support; the HOD Dr. Aruna Varanasi and their colleagues for creating a happy environment. Both authors K.E. and K.D.R, thank their spouses Suhasini and Amani respectively for their unwavering faith and encouragement.

sections.heading: 6. REFERENCES
sections.text: [1] K.Eswaran: A system and method of classification etc. Patents filed IPO No. (a) 1256 / CHE July 2006 and (b) 2669 / CHE June 2015 [2] K.Eswaran: On a non-iterative algorithm for separation of points in n-dimensional space by planes, 2015 (sent for publication): arxiv.org-abs-slash-abs-slash-slash-slash-1509.08742 [3] K.Eswaran: On the storage and retrieval of points in n-dimensional geometry, 2015, (sent for publication): arxiv.org-abs-slash-slash-1511.08941. Method 1 results: For testing we used 29 points, the points are: 5,10,15,20,25,25,35,45,45,50,55,60,65,70,80,90,90,95,100,105,110,115,120,125,130,135,140 and 145 (i.e. we used only every 5th point as a test point to avoid bias). For training we used 120 points, which represented the other points as test points.All equations of the levels are of the form: 1 + 1x1 + 2x2 + 3x3, each of which are predefined as 4x3.

metadata.abstractText: Recently an algorithm, was discovered, which separates points in n-dimension by planes in such a manner that no two points are left un-separated by at least one plane[1-3]. By using this new algorithm we show that there are two ways of classification by a neural network, for a large dimension feature space, both of which are non-iterative and deterministic. To demonstrate the power of both these methods we apply them exhaustively to the classical pattern recognition problem: The Fisher-Anderson’s, IRIS flower data set and present the results. It is expected these methods will now be widely used for the training of neural networks for Deep Learning not only because of their non-iterative and deterministic nature but also because of their efficiency and speed and will supersede other classification methods which are iterative in nature and rely on error minimization.
